John Estes (1899-1977) was an American blues singer, songwriter, and guitarist from Tennessee. He is often referred to as the "Delta Blues Master" and is considered one of the most influential blues musicians of all time.

Born on August 25, 1899, in Ripley, Tennessee, Estes grew up in a family of sharecroppers and was exposed to music from an early age. He began playing the guitar at the age of 15 and was heavily influenced by blues musicians such as Charlie Patton and Son House.

Estes developed his own unique style, which blended elements of Delta blues, country blues, and gospel music. He was known for his distinctive, gravelly voice and his mastery of the 12-string guitar, which he played with a slide. His songs often dealt with themes of love, heartache, and hardship, and were characterized by their emotional intensity and poetic lyrics.

Estes released several recordings in the 1930s and 1940s, including his debut single "Get Your Lash Ready" in 1935. He also recorded for various labels, including Victor Records and Decca Records. Despite his talent and influence, Estes struggled with poverty and personal problems throughout his life, and he died on June 5, 1977, at the age of 77.

Estes' music has been covered by many artists, including Eric Clapton, Led Zeppelin, and The Rolling Stones. He was inducted into the Blues Foundation's Blues Hall of Fame in 1980 and has been recognized as one of the most important figures in the development of the blues genre. Despite his passing, Estes' music continues to be celebrated and admired by blues enthusiasts around the world.

John Lee "Son" House was an American blues singer, songwriter, and guitarist from Mississippi. He is considered one of the most influential blues musicians of all time, known for his distinctive vocal style and unique guitar playing.

Born on March 30, 1902, in Lyon County, Mississippi, House grew up in a family of sharecroppers and began playing the guitar at a young age. He was largely self-taught and developed a distinctive style that blended elements of blues, gospel, and country music.

Despite his passing, John Lee "Son" House's music remains widely influential and continues to be celebrated by blues enthusiasts around the world. His unique style and contributions to the development of the blues genre have made him a legendary figure in the world of music.

Marie Alexandrine Becker (1841-1924) was a French photographer who was active during the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Desmond Doss was an American hero and a devout Seventh-day Adventist who served as a medic during the Korean War. He was born on February 7, 1926, in Lynchburg, Virginia, to Tom and Bertha Doss. Desmond was the fifth of twelve children in his family.

Doss grew up in a strong Christian household and was raised with a strong sense of faith. He was a pacifist and believed that he should not take a life, even in war. Despite this, he felt a strong sense of duty to serve his country and decided to enlist in the United States Army in 1949.

Doss was assigned to the 307th Infantry Regiment, 17th Infantry Division, and was trained as a medic. He was deployed to Korea in September 1950, where he served as a medic with the 307th Infantry Regiment.

Doss's most notable act of heroism came during the Battle of Pork Chop Hill, where he single-handedly carried 75 wounded soldiers to safety, often under heavy fire, and treated their wounds in a makeshift medical tent. He also saved the lives of two fellow soldiers who were mortally wounded and were about to be buried alive by enemy artillery fire.

Doss's actions during the war earned him numerous awards, including the Medal of Honor, the Bronze Star, and the Purple Heart. He was also awarded the Congressional Medal of Honor in 2015, 64 years after his heroics during the war.

Doss's story was immortalized in the 2016 film "Hacksaw Ridge," which tells the story of his experiences during the war. The film was directed by Mel Gibson and starred Andrew Garfield as Desmond Doss.

Desmond Doss passed away on March 23, 2006, at the age of 80, but his legacy lives on as an inspiration to people around the world. He is remembered as a hero who served his country with honor and compassion, and whose bravery and selflessness continue to inspire others to this day.

Lees Knowles (1878-1955) was a British mathematician and statistician who made significant contributions to the field of statistics and probability theory. Here's a brief bio:

Early Life and Education:
Lees Knowles was born on June 14, 1878, in Bury, Lancashire, England. He was the son of a cotton merchant and was educated at Bury Grammar School. Knowles then attended Owens College (now the University of Manchester) where he studied mathematics and graduated with a B.Sc. in 1901.

Career:
Knowles began his career as a mathematics teacher at Manchester Grammar School, where he remained for 15 years. During this time, he developed an interest in statistics and probability theory, which would become the focus of his later work.

In 1919, Knowles was appointed as a lecturer in mathematics at the University of Manchester, where he became a professor in 1924. He held this position until his retirement in 1946.

Research and Contributions:
Knowles' research focused on statistical theory, particularly in the areas of probability, statistics, and mathematical physics. He made significant contributions to the development of statistical inference, hypothesis testing, and the theory of estimation. His work also explored the application of statistical methods to problems in physics, engineering, and economics.

Some of his notable works include:

* "The Theory of Errors" (1924), which introduced the concept of the "Fisher-Knowles" distribution.
* "Statistical Theory of Errors" (1934), which developed the theory of statistical inference.
* "Probability and Statistics" (1941), a textbook that introduced probability theory to a wider audience.

Awards and Legacy:
Knowles was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society in 1925 and was awarded the Royal Society's Sylvester Medal in 1942 for his contributions to mathematics. He also served as the president of the Royal Statistical Society from 1945 to 1947.

Knowles passed away on March 24, 1955, leaving behind a lasting legacy in the field of statistics and probability theory. His work has continued to influence generations of statisticians and mathematicians, and his contributions remain an important part of the foundation of modern statistical theory.

Frederick Winslow Taylor (1856-1915) was an American mechanical engineer and management expert who is considered one of the most influential figures in the development of modern management theory. He is best known for his work in the field of scientific management, which aimed to improve industrial efficiency and productivity by analyzing and optimizing work processes.

Taylor was born in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, and grew up in a family of modest means. He was educated at Phillips Exeter Academy and later at Yale University, where he graduated in 1882 with a degree in mechanical engineering. After working as an engineer for several years, Taylor became fascinated with the inefficiencies and waste he observed in industrial processes. He believed that by analyzing and optimizing work processes, he could improve productivity and reduce costs.

In the late 1880s, Taylor began to develop his theories on scientific management, which he outlined in his 1911 book "The Principles of Scientific Management." In this book, Taylor argued that industrial efficiency could be improved by breaking down tasks into smaller, more manageable parts, and by training workers to perform each task in the most efficient way possible. He also advocated for the use of time-and-motion studies to analyze work processes and identify areas for improvement.

Taylor's ideas were revolutionary at the time, and he became a prominent figure in the management community. He was a strong advocate for the use of scientific methods to improve industrial efficiency, and he believed that workers should be trained and compensated based on their productivity and efficiency. He also believed that workers should be given more autonomy and responsibility, and that they should be involved in the decision-making process.

Taylor's ideas had a significant impact on the development of modern management theory, and his work influenced many other management experts, including Henry Ford and Mary Parker Follett. However, his ideas were not without controversy. Some critics argued that his emphasis on efficiency and productivity came at the expense of worker satisfaction and well-being, and that his approach was dehumanizing and de-skilling.

Despite these criticisms, Taylor's legacy continues to be felt today. His ideas about the importance of scientific management, efficiency, and productivity remain influential in many industries, and his work continues to be studied and debated by management scholars and practitioners around the world.

Jonathan Haagen-Smit was an American chemist and engineer who made significant contributions to the field of air pollution control. He was born on June 4, 1905, in New York City, USA.

Haagen-Smit studied chemical engineering at Columbia University, where he earned his bachelor's degree in 1926. He then went on to pursue his graduate studies at the University of California, Berkeley, earning his Ph.D. in 1930.

Haagen-Smit's research focused on the chemistry of air pollution, particularly the composition of smog and its effects on human health. In the 1940s and 1950s, he conducted extensive research on the Los Angeles smog problem, which was a major environmental issue at the time. He identified the main culprit behind the smog as the reaction between volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and nitrogen oxides (NOx) in the presence of sunlight.

Haagen-Smit's work led to the development of the "Haagen-Smit equation," which describes the chemical reactions involved in the formation of smog. His research also led to the implementation of air pollution control measures, including the use of scrubbers and catalytic converters to reduce emissions from vehicles and industrial sources.

Haagen-Smit was a prolific researcher and published numerous papers on air pollution and related topics. He was also an active member of various professional organizations, including the American Chemical Society and the Air Pollution Control Association. He served as the president of the Air Pollution Control Association from 1958 to 1959.

Throughout his career, Haagen-Smit received numerous awards and honors for his contributions to the field of air pollution control. He was also a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and a member of the National Academy of Engineering.

Haagen-Smit passed away on April 14, 1986, at the age of 80, leaving behind a legacy of groundbreaking research and contributions to the field of air pollution control.

Jonathan Haagen-Smit was a Dutch-American chemist who made significant contributions to the field of air pollution control and the development of air quality standards. He was born on May 8, 1905, in Amsterdam, Netherlands, to a Jewish family. Haagen-Smit's early life and education were marked by a fascination with chemistry, and he went on to study at the University of Amsterdam, where he earned his Ph.D. in organic chemistry in 1930.

Haagen-Smit's work in air pollution control began in the 1930s, when he became involved in the development of air pollution regulations in the Netherlands. He worked closely with the Dutch government to establish the first national air pollution standards, and his research focused on the chemistry of air pollution and the development of methods for reducing emissions.

In the 1940s, Haagen-Smit emigrated to the United States, where he joined the California Institute of Technology (Caltech) as a research professor of chemistry. At Caltech, he continued his research on air pollution, and his work focused on the development of methods for measuring and controlling air pollution.

One of Haagen-Smit's most significant contributions to the field of air pollution control was his discovery of the primary cause of Los Angeles' notorious smog problem. In the 1940s and 1950s, Los Angeles was plagued by severe air pollution, which was caused by the reaction of sunlight with the volatile organic compounds (VOCs) emitted by vehicles and industrial activities. Haagen-Smit's research showed that the main culprit behind the smog was the reaction between VOCs and nitrogen oxides (NOx), which formed ground-level ozone.

Haagen-Smit's work on smog formation and control led to the development of the first national air pollution standards in the United States, which were established in 1965. His research also led to the development of catalytic converters for vehicles, which have been instrumental in reducing emissions and improving air quality.

Throughout his career, Haagen-Smit was recognized for his contributions to the field of air pollution control. He was awarded the National Medal of Science in 1976 and was elected to the National Academy of Sciences in 1962. He passed away on November 14, 1982, at the age of 77, leaving behind a legacy of groundbreaking research and a significant impact on our understanding of air pollution and its control.
